ground_truth_articulation: Text is classified as TRUE if the variance in word lengths (excluding spaces) exceeds 8.0, indicating highly inconsistent word length distribution.
generated_articulation: In the True cases, the input contains at least one word with more than 10 letters (e.g., "implementation" and "incomprehensibility"), whereas in the False cases, all words are relatively short. Therefore, the pattern is that the input is classified as True if it includes at least one long word (more than 10 characters), and False otherwise.
raw_response: In the True cases, the input contains at least one word with more than 10 letters (e.g., "implementation" and "incomprehensibility"), whereas in the False cases, all words are relatively short. Therefore, the pattern is that the input is classified as True if it includes at least one long word (more than 10 characters), and False otherwise.
llm_judge_reasoning: The ground truth rule classifies texts as TRUE based on the variance in word lengths exceeding a threshold, which captures the overall distribution and inconsistency of word lengths in the input. In contrast, the generated rule classifies texts as TRUE if there is at least one very long word (more than 10 characters), focusing on the presence of a single long word rather than the overall distribution. While both rules relate to word length, they target different aspects: the variance versus the existence of a long word. They may often agree when texts contain multiple long words or highly variable word lengths, but they can diverge in cases where the variance is high due to many moderately long words, yet no single word exceeds 10 characters, or vice versa. Therefore, they do not describe the same core pattern and are unlikely to produce identical classifications consistently.
